Events.html: 756 – An Lushan Rebellion: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang is ordered by his Imperial Guards to execute chancellor Yang Guozhong by forcing him to commit suicide or face a mutiny. He permits his consort Yang Guifei to be strangled by his chief eunuch. General An Lushan has other members of the emperor's family killed.
Events.text: An Lushan Rebellion: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang is ordered by his Imperial Guards to execute chancellor Yang Guozhong by forcing him to commit suicide or face a mutiny. He permits his consort Yang Guifei to be strangled by his chief eunuch. General An Lushan has other members of the emperor's family killed.

Events.html: 1099 – First Crusade: Christian soldiers take the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem after the final assault of a difficult siege.
Events.text: First Crusade: Christian soldiers take the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem after the final assault of a difficult siege.

Events.html: 1149 – The reconstructed Church of the Holy Sepulchre is consecrated in Jerusalem.
Events.text: The reconstructed Church of the Holy Sepulchre is consecrated in Jerusalem.

Events.html: 1207 – King John of England expels Canterbury monks for supporting Archbishop Stephen Langton.
Events.text: King John of England expels Canterbury monks for supporting Archbishop Stephen Langton.

Events.html: 1240 – Swedish–Novgorodian Wars: A Novgorodian army led by Alexander Nevsky defeats the Swedes in the Battle of the Neva.
Events.text: Swedish–Novgorodian Wars: A Novgorodian army led by Alexander Nevsky defeats the Swedes in the Battle of the Neva.

Events.html: 1381 – John Ball, a leader in the Peasants' Revolt, is hanged, drawn and quartered in the presence of King Richard II of England.
Events.text: John Ball, a leader in the Peasants' Revolt, is hanged, drawn and quartered in the presence of King Richard II of England.

Events.html: 1410 – Polish–Lithuanian–Teutonic War: Battle of Grunwald – the allied forces of the Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeat the army of the Teutonic Order.
Events.text: Polish–Lithuanian–Teutonic War: Battle of Grunwald – the allied forces of the Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeat the army of the Teutonic Order.

links.subject: Kingdom of Poland
links.title: History of Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty

Events.html: 1482 – Muhammad XII is crowned the twenty-second and last Nasrid king of Granada.
Events.text: Muhammad XII is crowned the twenty-second and last Nasrid king of Granada.

Events.html: 1685 – Monmouth Rebellion: James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth is executed at Tower Hill, England after his defeat at the Battle of Sedgemoor on 6 July 1685.
Events.text: Monmouth Rebellion: James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth is executed at Tower Hill, England after his defeat at the Battle of Sedgemoor on 6 July 1685.

Events.html: 1741 – Aleksei Chirikov sights land in Southeast Alaska. He sends men ashore in a longboat, making them the first Europeans to visit Alaska.
Events.text: Aleksei Chirikov sights land in Southeast Alaska. He sends men ashore in a longboat, making them the first Europeans to visit Alaska.

Events.html: 1789 – Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette, is named by acclamation Colonel General of the new National Guard of Paris.
Events.text: Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette, is named by acclamation Colonel General of the new National Guard of Paris.

links.subject: Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette
links.title: Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette

Events.html: 1799 – The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign.
Events.text: The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign.

links.subject: Egyptian Campaign
links.title: French campaign in Egypt and Syria

Events.html: 1806 – Pike expedition: United States Army Lieutenant Zebulon Pike begins an expedition from Fort Bellefontaine near St. Louis, Missouri, to explore the west.
Events.text: Pike expedition: United States Army Lieutenant Zebulon Pike begins an expedition from Fort Bellefontaine near St. Louis, Missouri, to explore the west.

Events.html: 1815 – Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon Bonaparte surrenders aboard HMS Bellerophon.
Events.text: Napoleonic Wars: Napoleon Bonaparte surrenders aboard HMS Bellerophon.

Events.html: 1823 – A fire destroys the ancient Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls in Rome, Italy.
Events.text: A fire destroys the ancient Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls in Rome, Italy.

links.subject: Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls
links.title: Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls

Events.html: 1834 – The Spanish Inquisition is officially disbanded after nearly 356 years.
Events.text: The Spanish Inquisition is officially disbanded after nearly 356 years.

Events.html: 1838 – Ralph Waldo Emerson delivers the Divinity School Address at Harvard Divinity School, discounting Biblical miracles and declaring Jesus a great man, but not God. The Protestant community reacts with outrage.
Events.text: Ralph Waldo Emerson delivers the Divinity School Address at Harvard Divinity School, discounting Biblical miracles and declaring Jesus a great man, but not God. The Protestant community reacts with outrage.

Events.html: 1870 – Reconstruction Era of the United States: Georgia becomes the last of the former Confederate states to be readmitted to the Union.
Events.text: Reconstruction Era of the United States: Georgia becomes the last of the former Confederate states to be readmitted to the Union.

links.subject: Reconstruction Era of the United States
links.title: Reconstruction Era of the United States

Events.html: 1870 – Rupert's Land and the North-Western Territory are transferred to Canada from the Hudson's Bay Company, and the province of Manitoba and the Northwest Territories are established from these vast territories.
Events.text: Rupert's Land and the North-Western Territory are transferred to Canada from the Hudson's Bay Company, and the province of Manitoba and the Northwest Territories are established from these vast territories.

Events.html: 1888 – The stratovolcano Mount Bandai erupts killing approximately 500 people, in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.
Events.text: The stratovolcano Mount Bandai erupts killing approximately 500 people, in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.

Events.html: 1910 – In his book Clinical Psychiatry, Emil Kraepelin gives a name to Alzheimer's disease, naming it after his colleague Alois Alzheimer.
Events.text: In his book Clinical Psychiatry, Emil Kraepelin gives a name to Alzheimer's disease, naming it after his colleague Alois Alzheimer.

Events.html: 1916 – In Seattle, Washington, William Boeing and George Conrad Westervelt incorporate Pacific Aero Products (later renamed Boeing).
Events.text: In Seattle, Washington, William Boeing and George Conrad Westervelt incorporate Pacific Aero Products (later renamed Boeing).

Events.html: 1918 – World War I: The Second Battle of the Marne begins near the River Marne with a German attack.
Events.text: World War I: The Second Battle of the Marne begins near the River Marne with a German attack.

Events.html: 1920 – The Polish Parliament establishes Silesian Voivodeship before the Polish-German plebiscite.
Events.text: The Polish Parliament establishes Silesian Voivodeship before the Polish-German plebiscite.

Events.html: 1922 – Japanese Communist Party is established in Japan.
Events.text: Japanese Communist Party is established in Japan.

Events.html: 1927 – Massacre of July 15, 1927: Eighty-nine protesters are killed by the Austrian police in Vienna.
Events.text: Massacre of July 15, 1927: Eighty-nine protesters are killed by the Austrian police in Vienna.

Events.html: 1954 – First flight of the Boeing 367-80, prototype for both the Boeing 707 and C-135 series.
Events.text: First flight of the Boeing 367-80, prototype for both the Boeing 707 and C-135 series.

Events.html: 1955 – Eighteen Nobel laureates sign the Mainau Declaration against nuclear weapons, later co-signed by thirty-four others.
Events.text: Eighteen Nobel laureates sign the Mainau Declaration against nuclear weapons, later co-signed by thirty-four others.

Events.html: 1959 – The steel strike of 1959 begins, leading to significant importation of foreign steel for the first time in United States history.
Events.text: The steel strike of 1959 begins, leading to significant importation of foreign steel for the first time in United States history.

Events.html: 1966 – Vietnam War: The United States and South Vietnam begin Operation Hastings to push the North Vietnamese out of the Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone.
Events.text: Vietnam War: The United States and South Vietnam begin Operation Hastings to push the North Vietnamese out of the Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone.

Events.html: 1971 – The United Red Army is founded in Japan.
Events.text: The United Red Army is founded in Japan.

Events.html: 1974 – In Nicosia, Cyprus, Greek Junta-sponsored nationalists launch a coup d'état, deposing President Makarios and installing Nikos Sampson as Cypriot president.
Events.text: In Nicosia, Cyprus, Greek Junta-sponsored nationalists launch a coup d'état, deposing President Makarios and installing Nikos Sampson as Cypriot president.

Events.html: 1975 – Space Race: Apollo–Soyuz Test Project features the dual launch of an Apollo spacecraft and a Soyuz spacecraft on the first joint Soviet-United States human-crewed flight. It was both the last launch of an Apollo spacecraft, and the Saturn family of rockets.
Events.text: Space Race: Apollo–Soyuz Test Project features the dual launch of an Apollo spacecraft and a Soyuz spacecraft on the first joint Soviet-United States human-crewed flight. It was both the last launch of an Apollo spacecraft, and the Saturn family of rockets.

Events.html: 1979 – U.S. President Jimmy Carter gives his so-called malaise speech, where he characterizes the greatest threat to the country as "this crisis in the growing doubt about the meaning of our own lives and in the loss of a unity of purpose for our nation" but in which he never uses the word malaise.
Events.text: U.S. President Jimmy Carter gives his so-called malaise speech, where he characterizes the greatest threat to the country as "this crisis in the growing doubt about the meaning of our own lives and in the loss of a unity of purpose for our nation" but in which he never uses the word malaise.

Events.html: 1980 – A massive storm tears through western Wisconsin, causing US$160 million in damage.
Events.text: A massive storm tears through western Wisconsin, causing US$160 million in damage.

Events.html: 1983 – Orly Airport attack is launched by Armenian militant organisation ASALA at the Paris-Orly Airport in Paris; it leaves 8 people dead and 55 injured.
Events.text: Orly Airport attack is launched by Armenian militant organisation ASALA at the Paris-Orly Airport in Paris; it leaves 8 people dead and 55 injured.

links.subject: ASALA
links.title: Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia

Events.html: 1996 – A Belgian Air Force C-130 Hercules carrying the Royal Netherlands Army marching band crashes on landing at Eindhoven Airport.
Events.text: A Belgian Air Force C-130 Hercules carrying the Royal Netherlands Army marching band crashes on landing at Eindhoven Airport.

Events.html: 1997 – In Miami, Florida, serial killer Andrew Cunanan guns down Gianni Versace outside his home.
Events.text: In Miami, Florida, serial killer Andrew Cunanan guns down Gianni Versace outside his home.

Events.html: 2002 – "American Taliban" John Walker Lindh pleads guilty to supplying aid to the enemy and to possession of explosives during the commission of a felony.
Events.text: "American Taliban" John Walker Lindh pleads guilty to supplying aid to the enemy and to possession of explosives during the commission of a felony.

Events.html: 2002 – Anti-Terrorism Court of Pakistan hands down the death sentence to British born Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh and life terms to three others suspected of murdering The Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.
Events.text: Anti-Terrorism Court of Pakistan hands down the death sentence to British born Ahmed Omar Saeed Sheikh and life terms to three others suspected of murdering The Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl.

Events.html: 2003 – AOL Time Warner disbands Netscape. The Mozilla Foundation is established on the same day
Events.text: AOL Time Warner disbands Netscape. The Mozilla Foundation is established on the same day

Events.html: 2006 – Twitter is launched, becoming one of the largest social media platforms in the world.
Events.text: Twitter is launched, becoming one of the largest social media platforms in the world.
